title: What is the Dark Side of the Inner Child and how can you free yourself from its trances?
first_phrase: In the final chapter of this book, "The Dark Side of the Inner Child," Stephen, the author, reveals the importance of going beyond the trances of the inner child to awaken the observer and end the frozen states. He clarifies that each perceived trauma creates a strategy and identity, resulting in numerous inner children in one adult. The chapter contains exercises and examples to help readers identify and free themselves from these trances, as well as assisting professionals in working with their clients. Stephen, who lived in India for almost six years and is a psychotherapist, discovered meditation as a way of de-hypnotizing himself from his mental program.
content: This book is about going beyond the dark side of the inner child, and the trances of the inner child. To awaken the observerIcreator of the inner child is to end the trances of the inner child. In other words, awakening the observer ends the trance. Stated another way, to transcend the frozen states of the inner child you must end your trances. This is the real process of trance-ending.. I hope you enjoy the process. With love, Your brother, Stephen â€¢ 1 Where it All Began for Me For almost six years, I lived in a monastery in India. Before that, I conducted a private psychotherapy and training practice in Los Angeles, California. While in India it became apparent to me that meditation could be seen as an Eastern way of de-hypnotizing myself from my mental program, i.e., thoughts, feelings, and emotions. By de-hypnotizing myself I no longer felt compelled nor obsessed by the never ending chatter of the mind.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the process of awakening the observer and transcending the frozen states of the inner child is the real process of trance-ending. By de-hypnotizing ourselves through meditation and understanding the pervasive nature of trances, we can break free from the never-ending chatter of the mind and live more fully in the present moment. May you find joy and freedom in this journey. With love, Stephen.
